text: Before children learn to speak, they often show signs of understanding by responding to familiar words and phrases. Below are some common examples - does your child do any of these?
In the list below, please mark the phrases that your child seems to understand.
NOTE: It is a large inventory of words used by many different children across a wide age range, so do not worry if your child knows only a few of them at the moment!
U = only undersatnds; U&S = understands + says

Please mark the word even if your child only says the name of the person (e.g. “Adam” for “baby”). Please also put names of other people your child says and write down who they are in the comments section.
Please make sure you have completed all of the pages, before finishing this part. Did you mark all the words that your child understands/says?
When infants are learning to communicate they often use gestures to get a message across. For each of the gestures below, please mark the actions that you have seen your child do.
Does your child do or try to do any of the following?
Here are some things that young children sometimes do with stuffed animals or dolls. Please mark the actions that you have seen your child do.
Imitating other adult actions (Using real objects or toys)
